Quoting Kenneth Stanley <kstanley@...>:

> Colin, that sounds like a promising start!  How many generations did
> you run, what was your pop size, and did you get a chance to look at
> the winning structure at all?  One thing that's also always useful 
to
> check is that the number of species is reasonable over the 
run...huge
> explosions of species, or lack of species, can indicate a problem.

popsize was 150. The first few easy tasks were solved within the 
first dozen generations - which is behaviour I had witnesses before. 
Following that a plateau was reached after about 150-200 generations.

The number of species hovered around 40 to 70.

> 
> Can you give a little more info on what you mean by "amalgamate
> matching innovations per generation?"  I thought you meant 
refreshing
> the recorded list of innovation numbers each generation, but then 
when
> you ask whether I do this in the initial population as well, I'm not
> sure what you mean?  

Sorry, amalgamate isn't the right word. Yeh I did mean the refreshing 
(normalizing?) of the innovation ID's per generation. I currently 
generate a random population by linking each output to a single, 
randomly chosen input. My innovation ID's are being incremented 
during this phase - so yeh, I need to change this.
 
> As far as elitism, keep in mind each species should have its best
> member copied (as opposed to only the best in the population).  It
> definitely should make a positive difference in performance, 
assuming
> your species are not too small.

Thinking about thia again I realise that what I said isn't 100% 
correct. What I actually do is pure roulette wheel selection - but 
then the offspring get added to the existing population (therefore 
increasing it's size by 2x). I then cull the least fit 50%. So in 
effect I have implemented elitism - but the fittest individuals are 
not guaranteed to be selected for reproduction. This final point is 
what I'm intending to change.

>  Also, you should probably be using a
> dynamic speciation threshold if you are running more than 50
> generations or so.  If you don't know how to do this, let me know.

ok, i'll add it to the list and get back to you if I get stuck.
 
> On more question, is your prey domain animated so you can watch the
> solutions?

yes, I have a seperate program that can load in a given network and 
animate it. I hope to integrate visualization such as this more 
closely in the long run - this is just a quick hack really.

Regards,

Colin
